nodes.bodyText: why does it take so long to register nodes?
I am not exactly sure. There might be some parameters that we can tune to make it faster.
old calculation was wrong?

Gaining primacy in this test does not ensure all journal entries are applied. Sometimes a few entries are processed after the journal system is promoted and thus get ignored. The sequence number reflects entries that are processed which will include the entries processed before and after the follower becomes primary.
Is there any identifier we can add to this message?
AFAIK there is only one state machine per master. Is there a specific identifier you are looking for?
Ok. Is there a local path where the files will be initialized?
The local path where the journal logs and snapshots are stored is the journal directory set through the raft server configuration.
I'm curious. Why does reinitialize() and initialize() look completely different? I would have imagined that reinitialize would be quite similar to initialize, or would share some code?

initialize() is invoked when the server is first started. reinitialize() is invoked when a follower got a new snapshot from leader and need to reload.
There isn't much difference except maybe two things:

the initialize() does a little more to initialize the group id and raft storage.
mStorage.loadLatestSnapshot() was implicitly called in initialize() as part of mStorage.init(raftStorage);

Should be ERROR. Also, when does this happen? I don't know what this message is supposed to tell the user.
Why is this not throwing an exception instead?

A null snapshot is given if there isn't a snapshot in the journal folder. This can happen when the master is started for the first time or before a snapshot is taken. It is an expected case therefore is not logged as an error.
Do we need to log and throw the same exception?
I initially added the log for debugging. Removed.
I think if you use the logging with {}, you cannot use the last argument as the exception. You have to use String.format() to pass in a single string, and then the exception.
For slf4j we can pass an exception in addition to all string parameters to include the call stack in the log.
Should we throw a new exception with the message like above? Also, do we need to log and throw an exception?
Removed the logging message and included it in a new exception.
Do we need to throw and log? Can we have this message include the message above?
Removed the logging message.
Can you include the file name?
Added.
Include filename? Also, this message is identical to the previous section. Can we distinguish them?
Updated.
What about if this is not true? What would that happen, and do we want to log some sort of warning when that happens?
Yeah this should always be true given we only have one raft group. I will add a warning.
Can you update some of the comments in this file that still say copycat?
Updated.
If you want to use the exception as the last argument, you will have to use String.format() to print parameters.
IIRC in slf4j we can add one throwable in addition to the string parameters to print full exception stack: http://www.slf4j.org/faq.html#paramException
hrmmm, that is strange. I remember our logging messages would ignore the throwable, if we were using the string parameters...
Why using a fixed group id?
The raft group id associate the single state machine we have for master. We need it to be a constant for masters to join the right cluster when they start.
Change the comment as well?
Updated.
replace copycat in the comment
Updated.

I saw the examples of loading snapshots in initialize and reinitialize, but not sure why.
Are there guaranteed that all journal entries are included in the latest snapshot? will some journal entries after latest snapshot lost?
The snapshot does not have to include all entries. Ratis will catch up on entries after the snapshot before the server starts serving.
